holtPlane.history: Germany's first mass-produced military aircraft were called Tauben (Doves) -so named because of the bird-like shape of their wings. Austrian designer, Igo Etrich developed the first prototype Tauben, before licensing the design the Rumpler aircraft. Variants of Etrich's design were soon being produced by at least fourteen German and Austrian aircraft firms, including Gothaer Waggon-Fabrik (modeled here). The Gotha Tauben were designated LE 3 by the manufacturer and A.I by the German military. The Tauben featured a single aileron and unique split rudder configuration. Most variants, including the LE 3 were two-seat monoplanes. The LE 3 flew unarmed except for sidearms carried by pilots and served primarily in a reconnaissance role. Gotha delivered twenty LE 3s to the German Army in 1914. However, as the War began to accelerate military aircraft design and production, the Tauben were soon replaced by newer-model reconnaissance aircraft. A few served as trainers until 1917 when they were all retired.
holtPlane.deployment: This model represents an aircraft of an unidentified unit of the German Air Force, Western Front, August, 1914. Model Builder's Comments: The tail structure in this model deviates from the standard split rudder configuration found on most Taube aircraft.
